snippet.description:
The Ri's Andrew Marmery takes a break from Christmas Lecture rehearsals to describe how he designed a built a life-size Ames room for the show.
The distorted room was named after ophthalmologist Adelbert Ames, who invented the optical illusion in 1934. The floor, ceiling and side walls of the room are trapezoidal in shape but when viewed from a specific fixed point it appears to be rectangular.  As Andy demonstrates, anyone standing inside the room appears unusually large or unexpectedly small.

More about Ames Rooms http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ames_room

snippet.title: Tales from the Prep Room: The Ames Room

snippet.description:
Professor Bruce Hood shows an audience an images which changes with every blink, yet the audience fail to see big changes such as a disappearing tree and car. This is called change blindness. Everytime your eye blinks, your brain doesn't notice anything different unless you're paying special attention. The brain is regulating our behaviour by telling us what we have to pay attention to, it controls what we learn and how we remember. 

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture Two: Who's in charge here anyway?

snippet.title: Christmas Lectures 2011: Change Blindness

snippet.description:
Professor Bruce Hood shows an illusion which involves a sculpted face, but instead of the usual convex human face of a sculpture, the sculpture is flipped and we're shown the inside of the face but human brains find it hard to recognise it is convex until the head starts turning around. 

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture Three: Are you thinking what I'm thinking?

snippet.title: Christmas Lectures 2011: Einstein Hollow Mask

snippet.description:
Reality is created by the brain and uses past experiences to make sense of the world. But Professor Bruce Hood shows things are not always what they seem and demonstrates this with the Ames room and the Ponzo illusion. Bruce shows the brain is decieved by perceptive cues such as railway tracks and checked floors and the Ames Room can make people appear to shrink and grow!

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture One: What's in your head?

snippet.title: Christmas Lectures 2011: Shrinking and Growing; The Ames Room

snippet.description:
Professor Bruce Hood shows how our brain creates different interpretations of an Necker Cube which is an ambiguous line drawing. People find that their perception of  cube can change and this is further emphasised when the Necker Cube starts moving.

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture One: What's in your head?

View the full Lectures on the Ri Channel: 
www.richannel.org/christmas-lectures/2011/meet-your-brain
snippet.title: Christmas Lectures: Necker Cube Optical Illusion

snippet.description:
Professor Bruce Hood demonstratse the kanizsa illusion on the audience. The kanizsa illusion , named after the psychologist Gaetano Kanizsa, shows how our brain can create the illusion that an object exists when sections of a shape is removed. 

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture One: What's in your head?

snippet.title: Christmas Lectures 2011: Bruce Hood demonstrates the kanizsa illusion

snippet.description:
Professor Bruce Hood demonstrates the McGurk Effect on the audience. The McGurk Effect shows how our perception of what we hear is influenced by what we see such as the movement of people's lips when they speak. Try silently mouthing 'elephant juice' next time you see someone; what do they think you are saying?

This clip is part of the Christmas Lectures 2011 presented by Professor Bruce Hood - Lecture One: What's in your head?

snippet.title: Christmas Lectures 2011: McGurk Effect

snippet.description:
An evening of science-themed demos, fireside conversation and song. DemoJam 0 is the pilot of what we hope will be an ongoing web series.

Hosted by stand-up mathematician Matt Parker, the night combined brain-bending optics and a cuddly rhinovirus with a particle accelerator that won't work unless everyone in the room stops breathing.

Featuring Dr Ben Craven, physicist Suzie Sheehy, biologist Stephen Curry, and musical wizard Jonny Berliner (who summed up the night through the medium of song).

DemoJam 0 took place at the Ri on Wednesday 26 October 2011.
